My thoughts and prayers are with those affected by today's shooting in Ft. Lauderdale and the first responders who worked to save lives.
NA
NA

This past week I was honored to have the opportunity to host a bipartisan breakfast for the new members of Congress in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.   U.S. Rep. John Lewis, GA-5, was our speaker and shared his reflections on Dr. King, the civil rights movement, and the progress our country has made by working together for the public good.

Today, I joined my fellow Floridians to rally against the repeal of the   Affordable Care Act. Without the ACA 30 million Americans would  lose coverage and millions more will see costs increase.  I reject the current efforts underway to #MakeAmericaSickAgain.  #CoverageMatters #ACA
I had a great time celebrating the life and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. in Jacksonville this morning at the MLK Day Parade.
As we enter the last few hours of the Obama administration, I simply want to say thank you.  You will be missed.

I'm proud to support the women of this country.  Our wives, mothers, aunts, grandmothers, neighbors, friends, sisters, daughters, cousins, and strangers who marched today for equal rights for all. #womensMarch
My thoughts and prayers are with those affected by the severe weather this past weekend in North Florida. Glad to see the restoration efforts already underway by city officials. #FloridaStrong

Great meeting representatives from Jacksonville Head Start today. I am excited about the future and the opportunity to assist the children and families of the 5th Congressional District. #FloridaStrong

Just gave my first speech on the House floor today about the importance of protecting the Affordable Care Act. Repealing the ACA would leave many Floridians, and many Americans, without access to quality health care. #FloridaStrong

I am deeply disappointed by the President's Executive Order putting in place new vetting procedures for refugees and immigrants entering the United States. This executive order goes against everything this country stands for. I can think of few things more un-American than discriminating against people seeking refuge on our shores because of their religion.  This action betrays who we are as a country. Keeping the American people safe from threats from abroad is very important to me, but targeting an entire religion is completely misguided and irresponsible.   This order dishonors our values and has caused shockwaves of confusion throughout our nation. America is the land of opportunity regardless of age, race, class and religion. I will continue to work for smart action to protect our borders while protecting religious freedom and defending our American values.
My colleagues and I protested on the steps of the U.S. Supreme Court tonight in opposition to President Trump's Executive Order

I had the pleasure of sitting down with Duval County Public Schools Chairwoman Paula Wright to discuss ways in which we could work together to provide a high-quality education for all students in Jacksonville.     #FloridaStrong

It was an honor to be presented with the Army Seal by Lieutenant General Alan R. Lynn. I will display this seal proudly in my office in recognition of the hard working men and women of the U.S Army. Thank you for your service to our country.

I strongly oppose efforts to abolish the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Since its establishment 47 years ago, we have depended on the EPA to protect our air, water, and climate from harm.   In its first 20 years, EPA's Clean Air Act prevented more than 200,000 premature deaths and over 18 million cases of respiratory illness in children. This agency is an essential part of our government. The quality of all our lives are directly tied to this agency, I will support the EPA, NOT try to defund or eliminate it.  #DefendEPA  #DefendScience #FloridaStrong

We're proud to have Congressional Black Caucus Foundation intern and fellow Florida A&M University alum, Rashad Stafford, serving the people of Florida's 5th Congressional District. Join us in welcoming this Jacksonville native to #TeamLawson  #CD5 #FAMU #Rattlers Ì†ΩÌ∞ç#CBC #CBCF
Happy Valentine's Day to my beautiful wife Delores, and to everyone in FL-05!

In honor of Black History Month, yesterday on the House floor I recognized African-American trailblazers that paved the way for me to represent Florida‚Äôs 5th Congressional District. From renowned Tallahassee educator John G. Riley to Jacksonville‚Äôs Mary Singleton. I am grateful to those who came before me and left their mark in North Florida. Watch here to learn more.
On Wednesday, my Tallahassee office will be hosting mobile office hours in Madison! Come out between noon-3pm to the Madison County Courthouse Annex at 125 SW Range Ave, Madison, FL 32340.

With this vote, Jacksonville is on the right side of history in standing up for what is right and extending the Human Rights Ordinance to include our lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community. We must stand strong in protecting against discrimination based on race, religion, ethnicity, sexual orientation, or gender.  http://jacksonville.com/news/2017-02-14/historic-moment-jacksonville-lgbt-discrimination-protections-now-law-land

It was a pleasure to meet with Jim Murdaugh, President of Tallahassee Community College and TCC's District Board of Trustees to discuss ways in which we can work together to make college more affordable for students in North Florida.  #FloridaStrong #TCCEagles
Congratulations to the Maclay boys soccer team! #FloridaStrong

We had a great visit this morning at Jean Ribault High School where we met with the Lady Trojan basketball team and members of the 5000 Role Models of Excellence Project and talked about leadership and pursuing their dreams.

Yesterday afternoon, I had the opportunity to visit with residents like John Gatson (pictured) of Eureka Gardens Apartments in Jacksonville to learn first-hand about their living conditions. Like most Americans, the residents of Eureka Gardens want a clean, affordable, and safe place to call home. While we are encouraged by recent improvements, there is still work to be done. I will continue to talk with the residents at Eureka Gardens and the new management team to make sure we're doing all we can to improve the quality of life for residents.

Great things happen at Florida A&M University every day!   I am pleased to be at the FAMU School of Journalism & Graphic Communication today as they announced the launch date of the Black Television News Channel (BTNC) which will be housed at FAMU. BTNC is the first 24-hour African-American news network. This is an awesome opportunity for journalism students to gain real-world training before entering the workforce.#Florida5Strong #FAMU #FAMU1887 #1887 #SJGC #Rattlers
It was wonderful to join everyone celebrating #BlackHistoryMonth at the Harambee Festival today in Tallahassee!
‚Ä™Proud to have Florida A&M University interim President Dr. Larry Robinson joining me tonight for the President's joint session to Congress. ‚Ä¨

We heard a lot from President Trump tonight, but the numbers speak for themselves. Forty days after his inauguration, we still have yet to see President Trump and the Republican Congress lift a finger to create jobs or help hard-working Americans.   Instead, we have a leader who is alienating Americans instead of bringing people together. Trump and his administration are in a hurry to repeal the Affordable Care Act even if it makes America sick again and leaves 30 million people without life-saving health insurance. That is unacceptable.  Our country deserves better than a bunch of broken promises from our President. Now is the time for all of us in Congress to roll up our sleeves and figure out a way to work together in order to improve our economy, create more jobs, and do right by the people who sent us here to bring civility back to our government.  I am proud to represent Florida‚Äôs fifth Congressional district and will keep fighting to make sure the voice of Florida‚Äôs fifth is heard loud and clear in the halls of Congress.

There's nothing like a good book! Today, we celebrate National Read Across America Day. Here I am reading with my grandson, Cameron. Today, I challenge you to dedicate a small portion of your day to reading to the children in your lives. #ReadAcrossAmerica

I‚Äôm proud that Florida State College at Jacksonville is leading the way in becoming the first college in Florida to implement debt-free community college education through the Promise Grant, helping to reduce dependence on loans while also giving responsible students the job tools necessary to succeed. I look forward to continuing to work with FSCJ on efforts to improve higher education and the quality of life in our state.

Congratulations to the West Gadsden Panthers on winning the first boys basketball State title! http://www.tallahassee.com/story/sports/preps/2017/03/01/gadsden-county-west-basketball-wins-schools-first-state-title/98618198/

Today we kicked off #NationalSchoolBreakfastWeek at Fairview Middle School and @secondharvestofthebigbend because we know that kids need the right nutrition to do well in school. @USDANutrition #NoKidHungry #FoodIsFuel #schoolbreakfast

Today in honor of International Women‚Äôs Day we take time to pay tribute to the incredible contributions women have made to our global communities.  Throughout our collective lifetimes, we have seen women win the right to vote, get elected to public office from the city council to the United States Senate, and achieved remarkable feats in every aspect of our society ‚Äì from finding cures for cancer, to writing the great American novel, to defending civil rights, to coaching talented college basketball teams.  This year is a bit different from years past though. We have been moved to greater action to show the power women have in our workplaces, the marketplace, and in homes around the world. Today I wear red in solidarity with A Day Without A Woman, in recognition of the enormous value that women add to our economy and our society. Yet women receive lower wages, experience greater inequities, discrimination, and job insecurity. I believe in the human rights of women and we must join together to be bold for change at this time when we need it most.
Anyone interested in learning more about our military service academies, please come out this Saturday in Tallahassee to learn more.
Got my bracket ready for #MarchMadness and have FSU Hoops going to the #FinalFour - Go Noles!

The Republican plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act is an exercise in smoke and mirrors. We need to put aside the partisan bickering, roll up our sleeves, and get to work. I will continue to fight to make health care affordable and accessible for all Americans, not just a select few. Read more here - http://www.tallahassee.com/story/opinion/2017/03/21/lawson-aca-replacement-simply-unacceptable/99458994/

Proud to join Joe Biden and House Democrats to #ProtectOurCare and celebrate 7 years of the #AffordableCareAct - which has made it possible for more than 20 million Americans to get the health insurance they need and deserve.
Thanks to Roll Call for coming to talk with me about #MarchMadness and my love of gardening and spending time with my grandkids. http://www.rollcall.com/news/take-five-al-lawson
Amazing generosity in #FL5 today - Supervalu in Quincy donated $15,000  to Second Harvest of the Big Bend to help Gadsden County families. #FightingHunger #GadsdenStrong

It‚Äôs amazing to see how far we‚Äôve come in the last 7 years. 20 million Americans insured and counting. Hundreds of millions more empowered to take ownership of their health care. That‚Äôs progress like we haven‚Äôt seen in decades. And it couldn‚Äôt have happened without the Affordable Care Act! #ACA7 We cannot turn the clock back on progress.

Today is a victory for the American people who have made their voices heard loud and clear - they do not want repeal and replace. What we must do now is come together to work to improve the Affordable Care Act. It took us centuries to get to where we are now with our health care, and we‚Äôve already helped 20 million people get the health care they need. Let‚Äôs improve the ACA to see how we can help even more people get the health care they need and deserve.
I stand with Americans and their right to #privacy. Corporations should not be able to sell your personal info. #BroadbandPrivacy

Enjoyed meeting with Florida's AIPAC ‚Äì The American Israel Public Affairs Committee members and discussing the importance of the Israel Ì†ºÌ∑ÆÌ†ºÌ∑±and United States Ì†ºÌ∑∫Ì†ºÌ∑∏relationship. #AIPAC2017

Hundreds of Save the Children US advocates are on the Hill today, and it was wonderful to meet with these Floridians to talk about the importance of early childhood education and maternal and newborn health. #InvestInKids
We won‚Äôt stand for attacks on @PPACT. We #StandWithPP and the 2.5 million who rely on them. #PinkOut

Women in Florida are paid 85 cents for every dollar paid to men, mounting to an annual wage gap of $6,203. Among Florida women who hold full-time, year-round jobs, African American women are paid 61 cents, Latinas are paid 60 cents and Asian women are paid 76 cents for every dollar paid to white, non-Hispanic men. That must change. Women's paychecks should reflect the enormity of their contributions to our economy. That‚Äôs why I support the Paycheck Fairness Act. #EqualPay for all!

I am looking forward to meeting with the citizens this week and hearing their concerns at my town hall meetings during the April recess. The first of my town halls will be in Jacksonville this Wednesday, April 12th at 6:00 PM. Please visit my website for additional details.  I hope to see you there.   https://lawson.house.gov/media/press-releases/lawson-hold-town-halls-april

I‚Äôm so glad HUD Secretary Ben Carson heeded my call and came down to Jacksonville to talk with residents at Eureka Gardens and hear first-hand what they need from the federal government. We need to make sure we are doing all we can to hold people accountable for improving all the units here so that residents can have a clean, affordable and safe place to raise their families and call home.  https://lawson.house.gov/media/press-releases/lawson-tours-eureka-gardens-hud-secretary
Thank you to the City of Jacksonville, for inviting me to speak this evening about what's been happening in Washington and my work for #FL5.
It was great hearing from #Jacksonville small business owners this morning. We talked about access to capital, financial literacy, and expanding opportunities for entrepreneurs.
I am looking forward to meeting with the citizens of Jacksonville this evening at my first town hall at 6:00 PM, FSCJ- Downtown Campus..  I hope to see you there.
Thank you to everyone in Jacksonville who came out to our town hall this evening. It was wonderful to hear from so many of you.
Had a chance this morning to see some #toyotas in #Jacksonville at JM Family Enterprises and learned from workers that 70% of Toyota's car parts are made in the U.S.

I'm looking forward to hearing from you in Tallahassee at our town hall meeting tomorrow, Tuesday, April 18, from 6-8 p.m. at Bethel Family Life Center at 406 North Bronough Street. You can RSVP here - https://www.eventbrite.com/e/us-rep-al-lawson-town-hall-tickets-33322418250  Hope to see you there!
Getting ready to start our town hall at Bethel Family Life Center, come join us #Tallahassee from 6-8pm.

Thank you to the Tallahassee American Legion Post 13 for coming to talk with me about veterans issues and what we need to do to make sure we are doing all we can for our brave men and women when they come home.
It is truly an honor to serve the people of Florida's fifth. I will continue to fight on your behalf each and every day on issues that are important to you.
Beautiful day for the Madison County Down Home Days Parade. Thanks to everyone who joined us!
This #EarthDay2017 we must do all we can to protect the beautiful natural wonders we are so fortunate to have in Florida and across the U.S.

#TrumpCare would force families to pay higher premiums and deductibles, kick millions of Americans off their health insurance, gut key protections including those for people with pre-existing conditions, impose an #AgeTax on older Americans, and shorten the life of the Medicare Trust Fund. Democrats know that health care is a right, not a privilege and we will continue to fight for America‚Äôs families to have access to affordable care.

We all agree that tax reform is much needed for our nation‚Äôs students, families, and small businesses but trump‚Äôs proposed tax reform lacks detail. Our country deserves to know how any tax reform measure will impact their pockets, their business, and their families.
Proud to be a co-chair along with Representative Ted Yoho for the Florida State Society annual Stone Crab Stomp in DC! #StoneCrab2017 #FLStateSociety

We have heard a lot of big ideas and promises from the President, but we haven't seen much in tangible action from the Republicans over the last 100 days. We know we need to continue to improve health care in this country, yet republicans have failed to come up with a reasonable solution.  As someone who spent 36 years working in the insurance business, I stand ready and willing to work with my colleagues to improve health care for my constituents in Florida‚Äôs fifth district. We also need to focus our energy on creating jobs here in America. What we don't need are more antics from the President who is more focused on settling scores from the campaign trail than finding real solutions.   It's a sad day in America when Congress can't come together to make real progress for the American people. We need to put partisan bickering aside and roll up our sleeves and get to work. That's something we should all be able to do in the next 100 days, and I implore my colleagues to join me in doing what's right.

I was very pleased to invite Deborah K. Thompson, President of the National Association of Black Women in Construction to Capitol Hill to discuss issues important to the small businesses with committee democrats.

President Trump is still playing political games with our government. Threatening to shut down the government is irresponsible and puts ideology ahead of sound policy. We need to be coming together to figure out how to make meaningful progress for the American people - and that includes funding our government so that we can serve the people who elected us to do just that.   The last time the Republicans shut down the government in 2013, it cost our economy $24 billion and 120,000 jobs. We were not sent to Washington to throw temper tantrums, and I implore the President and my Republican colleagues to put aside their partisan grandstanding and get to work. We have plenty to do, and no time to waste.
Thank you to The National Urban League for honoring Congressman Donald McEachin, Anthony Brown, U.S. Representative Val Demings & me with the #RisingStar award last night.
Proud to join Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Inc. for Kappas on Capitol Hill.

Despite President‚Äôs Trump‚Äôs desire to play political games with our government, cooler heads have prevailed and we have passed legislation that will ensure our federal government is fully funded through the end of September. This final deal stands in stark contrast to President‚Äôs Trump‚Äôs initial draconian budget request that called for gutting billions from lifesaving medical research, paying to construct a border wall, defunding planned parenthood, and undermining the Affordable Care Act.   What we passed is far better for the American people. We increased funding for the National Institutes of Health by $2 billion, so that vital medical research can continue. Democrats also fought to restore students‚Äô access to year-round Pell Grants, secured funding to help stem the opioid epidemic, and secured $1.1 billion in disaster assistance for regions affected by storms and flooding, and we extended health insurance benefits for retiring mine workers. We also have more than $800 million going toward making our nation‚Äôs drinking water safe, and another $100 million going specifically to Flint, Michigan to upgrade their drinking water infrastructure. Another several million will go to our nation‚Äôs historically black colleges and universities.  We will work to hold the Trump Administration accountable for upholding their end of the agreement ‚Äì such as fulfilling their pledge to continue payments critical to the success of Affordable Care Act exchanges. I‚Äôm proud that members of Congress were able to come together to do what‚Äôs right and make meaningful progress for the American people.

There is absolutely no excuse for House Republicans‚Äô race to kick 24 million off their health coverage. As they say, sunlight is the best disinfectant. Tune in below to watch the floor debate on #Trumpcare - https://www.facebook.com/housebudgetdems/videos/10154671801774952/

Republicans have lost sight of why constituents sent us to Washington D.C. ‚Äì and it wasn‚Äôt to score political points with President Donald Trump. This abomination of a health care disaster will raise health care premiums, deductibles and out-of-pocket costs for hard-working Americans while at the very same time, giving $600 billion in tax breaks to big corporations.   Some estimated 24 million Americans could lose their health care coverage under this new bill, while those with pre-existing conditions will be at the mercy of their state leadership, which could opt out of guaranteeing them access to affordable health care. Trumpcare will allow insurance companies to charge people 50 and over five times more than they charge other people and it weakens the life of the Medicare trust fund.  None of us can choose when and where we will need emergency care, or when we might join the millions of Americans who already have pre-existing conditions. No one should live in fear of not being able to seek medical care because it might lead to higher premiums they cannot afford.   We need to make it easier to access and afford health care in our country, and Republicans have not put us on the path to do that. Rather they have taken us back in time and created more obstacles for those who need it most to get the health care they need.
I enjoyed worshiping with Pastor Marvin C. Zanders, II and the good people of Saint Paul A.M.E. Church this morning.
Proud to join the National Association of Letter Carriers in Jacksonville today to encourage our communities to come together to Stamp Out Hunger on May 13, this Saturday.

Had a great time in the City of Lake City today talking with constituents and local leaders like City Clerk Audrey Sikes and Councilmember Jake Hill, Jr. Thanks to all who came out to share your ideas and questions! #FL5
The American people deserve to know the truth about the full Russia investigation and we need an independent special prosecutor to oversee it.  #ComeyFiring

Congratulations to Savannah Rahn of Douglas Anderson School of the Arts for being recognized for her amazing work ‚ÄúDollar Tree Bicycle‚Äù - looking forward to displaying your artwork in the United States Capitol. #FL5 #artseducation
We need to put aside partisan bickering, roll up our sleeves, and get to work to improve health care. Read my take in today's The Hill https://goo.gl/wRFLME
My thoughts and prayers are with Rep. Brown, her family, and all those affected. I believe Jacksonville is a better place because of her three decades of public service.

Many Winn-Dixie stores have helped reduce food deserts in parts of North Florida and across the Southeast. This is unfortunate to learn that some stores in Jacksonville and Tallahassee will be closing. We know that access to food is a real issue in our community. Next week, the new Secretary of Agriculture, Sonny Perdue, will be appearing before the House Agriculture Committee and I plan to make him aware of our District‚Äôs need for access to food and grocery stores. http://www.tallahassee.com/story/money/2017/05/10/winn-dixie-closing-south-side-store/101509914/ and http://jacksonville.com/business/metro/2017-05-11/jacksonville-based-winn-dixie-quietly-closing-stores

Pleased to be able to participate in the Tallahassee Emancipation Day activities, celebrating the end of slavery in the United States, and the closing of a chapter in American history that will forever scar our national conscience.

Reports of President Trump sharing highly sensitive information with Russian officials is extremely concerning. This underscores the need for a Special Prosecutor to investigate this administration‚Äôs ties to Russia. https://goo.gl/2yssS5

On Wednesday, the newly confirmed Secretary of Agriculture, Sonny Perdue, will visit the House Agriculture Committee to outline his vision for the U.S. Department of Agriculture. As a proud member of this committee, and an enthusiastic thought leader on the Nutrition Subcommittee, I look forward to representing the interests of northeast Florida. One of my top concerns that I plan to bring up to the Secretary is our district‚Äôs struggles with hunger and food insecurity. Read more here - https://goo.gl/sDNM5j
My Tallahassee office will host mobile office hours on Wednesday, May 17, in Madison at the County Commission Annex from noon-3 pm. Come out and ask your questions and let us know how we can help.

Tune in to CSPAN3 this morning to watch the House Agriculture Committee live as we talk with the new Secretary of Agriculture, Sonny Perdue, about the rural economy and what we can do to help. https://www.c-span.org/video/?428489-1/agriculture-secretary-sonny-perdue-testifies-rural-economy
Thanks to the wonderful realtors who met with me today to discuss meaningful solutions to home affordability.

Appointing former FBI Director Robert Mueller as a special counsel is a step in the right direction for continuing the investigation into Russia‚Äôs possible involvement in our democracy, but we still need an independent commission in order to ensure a thorough investigation. The American people deserve to know the full truth.
Our thoughts and prayers are with #Manchester and the United Kingdom for all the victims of tonight's attack. Such sad news.

Once again, President Trump‚Äôs budget calls for extreme cuts to vital funding for programs that help our nation‚Äôs poor, from health care and food stamps to student loans and disability payments. It is a short-sighted plan that seeks to give tax breaks to the wealthiest while taking away lifelines for those who need it most.  In my district, one in every four Floridians has been on food stamps at some point over the last 12 months. That is twice the national average. It is unconscionable for the President to propose cutting nutrition benefits at any level, because any reduction would mean less for those in North Florida who need it most. Every day, children who qualify for free breakfast and lunch attend school and are fed the only meals they will receive that day because their parents can‚Äôt afford to feed them. We put hard-working Floridians in the no-win position of having to choose between paying their light bill or affording healthy food. This is unacceptable.  This budget calls for slashing $800 billion from Medicaid over the next decade, another $192 billion from nutritional assistance, and $72 billion from disability benefits. It calls for eliminating loan programs that subsidize college education for the poor and for those who take jobs in the government or nonprofit organizations. At a time when we need to be working to make college more affordable and accessible in order to prepare the next generations for tomorrow‚Äôs jobs, this is counterproductive to the President‚Äôs own stated goals.  This budget continues corporate welfare for Wall Street and major corporations, while forcing those who can afford it the least to sacrifice the most. I believe that our national budget is a reflection of our values as a society and this does not align with the values of Florida‚Äôs fifth Congressional district, and therefore I intend to strongly oppose it. I will continue to stand firmly for all Americans who need a helping hand in order to find jobs, support their families, contribute to growing our economy and to what makes America a great place to call home.
Thanks to the Florida Trucking Association for meeting with me to discuss the importance of improving our infrastructure and keeping our roads and bridges safe.
Talked with Florida's own Southeast Milk about how to educate and inspire the next generation about the #dairy industry. #FL5
Thanks to Moniece Jackson for being a strong advocate for #FosterYouthVoices. Good luck as you graduate from Florida State University soon!

Need help with a federal agency or department?  Come see us during our mobile office hours on Friday, May 26 in Macclenny.  A representative from my office will be available to meet with you, listen to your concerns and address any problems you may have with a federal or state agency. Come to the City Hall Commission Chambers at 118 E Macclenny Ave any time between 10 a.m. - 1 p.m. #FL5

As we mark this Memorial Day, we pause to honor the ultimate sacrifice paid by so many of our brave men and women in uniform. We honor them by sharing and remembering their legacies.  We also honor them by making sure we are doing all we can to care for our veterans when they return home. For it is through their valiant efforts that our democracy lives on, and now more than ever, that is to be honored and cherished.  One of my priorities in Congress is working to ensure our veterans are getting the help they deserve - from education, to job training, access to health care, and affordable housing. We must never, ever, forget the sacrifice our veterans and their families have made. Every generation has fought to preserve our freedom and defend life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness, and every generation has lost servicemen and women in that defense. We are grateful for their service to our nation.

So proud that the Veterans Affairs Jacksonville Outpatient Clinic hosted a dedication ceremony today to honor our blind veterans with a Bronze Braille Flag - http://jacksonville.com/news/military/2017-05-31/braille-flag-jacksonville-va-clinic-sends-message-hope-blind-community

I am extremely disappointed that President Trump plans to pull the United States out of the Paris Climate Agreement. This noble agreement will allow countries to finally tackle the issue of climate change and help protect our communities around the world. We need to be working together to improve our environment so that we ensure future generations can enjoy the same national treasures like the Everglades, coastlines, and beautiful state parks so many enjoy in Florida.
Thank you to everyone who joined us in Jefferson today for our farming forum. It was wonderful to hear from so many in our community about how we can work together to help feed America.
Thank you to everyone at UPS in the Tallahassee hub for coming out this morning to talk with me.
Great meeting with the Florida Health Care Association today to discuss how we can work together to improve care in nursing facilities throughout FL's 5th District!

Congratulations to Tallahassee's own Shacafrica Simmons, aka Chef Shac, for great success on Chopped! http://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/2017/06/07/tallahassee-chef-whips-competition-chopped/376367001/
After former FBI Director James Comey‚Äôs testimony today, it's clearer than ever that an independent commission into the Trump-Russia connection is needed. We need to #FollowTheFacts.

I pause today to reflect and remember the men and women we lost at Pulse Night Club one year ago, today.  They were sons, daughters, soliders, friends, family and our fellow Americans.   I mourn with their loved ones and stand with the citizens of Orlando, and Florida, to show that we will not let hate win. #OrlandoUnited #WeWillNotLetHateWin

‚Ä™Our thoughts and prayers are with Steve Scalise, the U.S. Capitol Police,  and others who were shot this morning. This is such terrible and disheartening news. ‚Ä¨We must stand together during this difficult time.
Had a great time hearing from the Tri-County Electric Cooperative Inc and Talquin Electric Cooperative and all the great students and future leaders of the Big Bend!

Talked about #Jacksonville priorities with the JAX Chamber today - from boosting innovation in small businesses to #FloridaAgriculture. Thanks to everyone who took time to come meet with me and my staff.

Proud that we‚Äôre breaking ground on Jacksonville Transportation Authority‚Äôs regional transportation center. When completed, this multi-modal hub, located in Downtown Jacksonville will integrate key local, regional and intercity service in one location. This is a great day for Jacksonville!
HAPPENING NOW: Joining my colleagues to reaffirm our #CommitmenttoCivility.
Excited to cheer on my colleagues as they #BeatThePress tonight in the Congressional Women's Softball Game to help young cancer survivors! #GoCongress

I was honored to present Lincoln High School graduate Jean-Paul Recht with the Congressional Award Gold Medal for his incredible contributions to our community. These awards are given to young people who complete over 400 hours of community service. Jean-Paul has completed projects ranging from Coastal Cleanups to building ramps for the handicapped. May we all be inspired by students like Jean-Paul and all they do for #FL5!

Enjoyed talking with the Associated Builders & Contractors - Florida First Coast Chapter and the Associated Builders and Contractors of North Florida about the importance of access to capital for small businesses and increasing technical education and workforce development in #FL5.

We have to stand up against harmful cuts that hurt those who can least afford it. This is unacceptable. "Forty-three million Americans rely on SNAP. More than half of SNAP recipients are children or the elderly. Many are low-wage workers, trying to make ends meet in jobs that don‚Äôt pay enough to keep food on the table. Many more are families in extreme poverty ‚Äî the 45% of the poor whose incomes are below half of the poverty line or below $850 in income a month for a family of three ‚Äî for whom SNAP is a literal lifeline." http://time.com/4838245/trump-health-care-congress-food-stamps/

"Where liberty is, there is my country." --- Benjamin Franklin I wish everyone a safe and fun Independence Day. As we celebrate our nation's 241st birthday, let us continue to embody that American spirit.  Happy 4th of July!

Thank you to everyone who came out this morning to the Beaver Street Veterans Villas in Jacksonville. We must keep doing all we can to ensure our veterans are getting the benefits they deserve after serving our country so honorably - from entrepreneurship opportunities, to job training programs, to access to health care, education benefits, and affordable housing options. If you are a veteran who needs help, please contact my office or email me here: https://lawson.house.gov/emailal

Today, the House of Representatives passed the National Defense Authorization Act of 2018 (NDAA). This bill is an important step forward in providing resources for national security while also supporting local economies. NDAA includes provisions that will build three Littoral Combat Ships, which directly supports jobs in Jacksonville. NDAA also authorizes funding for 87 F-35 fighter jets, 17 more than the President‚Äôs request and includes H.R. 1680, the Women‚Äôs Business Centers Improvement Act, a bipartisan measure I introduced with Republican Congressman Steve Knight and Democratic Congresswoman Stephanie Murphy, which provides additional funding and resources to Women Business Centers. I look forward to continuing to work with my colleagues to strengthen our national security while also supporting local economies across my district.

Yesterday I joined with Congressman John Rutherford and the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs to host a briefing on Capitol Hill about veterans mental health to find out how we can make sure we're doing all we can to take care of our brave men and women who have defended our great country.

Today in the Small Business committee we discussed how banks can work with community partners to increase access to capital, the impact student debt has on entrepreneurial growth, and how we can assist veterans with starting their own businesses and what else can congress do to help with small business development.

This week Leon County is holding voter outreach and education drives throughout the Big Bend as part of an effort between the American Association of People with Disabilities and EveryLibrary to bring National Disability Voter Registration Week 2017 to libraries across the country. Equal access to the ballot box regardless of personal circumstance is something that I deeply value. I encourage everyone to stop by their local Leon County Library and participate in this week‚Äôs events. Find out more here - https://goo.gl/8wNesc

Today, I introduced the Student Opportunity Act to provide economic relief for those who have student loans. This bill would make it possible for people with high federal student loan debt to refinance their loans at a lower rate, and it would ensure future students can afford loan financing. It also would eliminate the tax penalty for loan balance forgiveness. Reducing student debt will help increase economic activity and provide our nation‚Äôs students with the relief and opportunity they deserve.

One of my priorities in Congress is working to ensure our veterans are getting the help they deserve - from job training, to access to health care and education benefits, to finding affordable housing. Our brave men and women who have fought for our freedom deserve to be taken care of when they return home. That‚Äôs why today I introduced the Veterans Jobs Opportunity Act to help encourage veterans to pursue their dream of starting a small business in our communities around the country. Read more about it here - https://goo.gl/Wa31Zo

The news out of Virginia is very troubling.  We see clear as day that the struggle for equality and acceptance in this country is far from over. We cannot afford to go backward as a nation. No good comes from senseless bloodshed and we cannot let hate thrive and further divide us. We know that Social Security is vital for so many Americans, and it is the most successful anti-poverty, longstanding program of all-time. Today marks 82 years since it was signed into law. Are you in Jacksonville and looking for a way to help those in need in Texas? Please consider donating bottled water and non-perishable supplies such as canned foods, diapers, etc. Please bring your donations between 7 a.m. - 7 p.m. to the International Longshoremen Association at Local 1408 at 2040 E 21st ST in Jacksonville and they will deliver to those in need. On this Labor Day I pay tribute to the working men and women to whom America owes so much. I also give thanks for the fact that in our free society--more than anywhere else on earth--the laborer can enjoy' the results of his/her labor and the freedom to choose where and how he/she will apply his/her skills.  In a competitive world, no matter how great our past achievements, we must not fall victim to complacency. The soul and sinew of American labor must continue to be a force for progress and productivity. For all of us, Labor Day 2017 should be a time of rededication and thanksgiving, a time when we renew our dedication to preserving an abundant America, free and secure, for this and future generations.

President Trump‚Äôs decision to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program is terribly wrong and heartless. His actions needlessly target children who know no other country as home than America, and will rip apart families.  It tells people who have worked hard for years to become Americans that they have to leave the country. This action does not make our communities safer or our economy stronger.   I will do everything I can to prevent this from becoming a reality.

Without electrical power?  After a major storm has passed and it is safe for electrical crews to work,  power companies typically assess the damage to  the electrical grid and begin the restoration process.   Crews generally restore power in the sequence that will result in returning service to the greatest number of customers as soon as possible  In you are experiencing electrical power outages,here are contact numbers in each county:   Duval: Jacksonville Electric Authority (JEA)  (800) 683-5542 904-665-6000 or you can also text OUT to 69532  Baker/Columbia/Hamilton: Florida Power & Light  (800) 226-3545  Madison/Jefferson: Tri-County Electric Co-Op Inc  (850) 973-2285  Leon: Talquin Electric Customers 1.888.802.1832  City of Tallahassee Electric Customers 850-891-4968  Gadsden: Talquin Electric Co-Op Inc  (850) 878-4414

Today I filed two amendments to the tax reform bill to aid veterans who want to start their own small businesses and to help ease the burden of student loan debt on our nation‚Äôs students.   My first amendment will provide a tax credit for veterans who open a business in an under served community, the second will erase the tax burden that accompanies student loan debt.   These important amendments will help support our nation‚Äôs veterans and students.

This morning, I held a Capitol Hill briefing with U.S. Rep. Danny Davis (IL)  Mazon, Share Our Strength, and FRAC to bring attention to hunger on our nation's college campuses.   The briefing was also in support of my bill H.R.3875 - College Student Hunger Act of 2017.  According to one national study 25% of all community colleges students and 20% of four-year college students surveyed reported going hungry in the pervious 30 days.  In Florida‚Äôs 5th Congressional District, several higher educational institutions such as the University of North Florida, Tallahassee and North Florida Community Colleges, Florida A&M University, Florida State College at Jacksonville, and Florida Gateway College, among others, have adopted a deliberate response against hunger by opening food banks on campus.
